The electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) has emerged as a potentially excellent substitute to the highly resource-intensive Haber-Bosch process for ammonia synthesis, attracting a surge of interest among researchers and industry professionals in recent years. Nevertheless, the selectivity and Faradaic efficiency (FE) of the NRR in solution are significantly diminished, which necessitates an intensive search for efficient and selective nitrogen electrocatalysts to improve the reaction performance. This review meticulously surveys the advancements in single-atom (SACs), dual-atom (DACs), and nanocluster nitrogen-fixing electrocatalysts that have been made in recent times. It encompasses a detailed exploration of the pathway and mechanism of the NRR, as well as an analysis of the various types of electrocatalysts and their distinctive features. Moreover, the review underscores the challenges inherent in this reaction, discusses catalyst design strategies that have been employed to address these obstacles, and highlights potential avenues for enhancing the overall efficiency and effectiveness of nitrogen fixation processes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen reduction reaction Single-atom catalysts Dual-atom catalysts Nanocluster catalysts Electrocatalyst Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is a crucial chemical feedstock in the production of fertilizers, supporting global population growth as well as the development of new energy as a green energy carrier and alternative fuel. It is additionally utilized as a storage and conversion medium for energy [1–3]. The Haber–Bosch process, one of the most significant inventions of the twentieth century [4], is being used to synthesize industrial ammonia, which has been widely recognized as a dominant industrial processes for fixing nitrogen (N2) by converting atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia. It uses the direct reaction of N2 and H2 to generate NH3 ( N 2 + 3 H 2 → 2 N H 3 ), which serves as the basis for the synthesis of NH3 on a wide scale in industry [5,6]. However, as a consequence of the enormous bond energy of the NN bond (941 kJ mol−1), the procedure unavoidably calls for the primary combination of high pressures (15–25 MPa) and high temperatures (400–550 °C) [7]. Not only does it need a lot of energy (about 1 % to 2 % of the world's total energy supply is consumed annually), but also emits a large amount of warm chamber gases (accounting for about 1.5 %) [5], which may cause some adverse global environmental changes. Confronted with increasing demand for NH3, the environment cannot afford the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process. Therefore, it is imperative to explore and develop an environmental, sustainable and alternative NH3 manufacturing technique as well as an efficient catalyst for NRR. Currently, Researchers have created a variety of catalysts for NRR, which are utilized in systems that are powered by electricity or light. The photocatalytic reduction of nitrogen to ammonia using inexhaustible sunlight has been extensively investigated as a synthesis [8,9]. Numerous metal-decorated/doped semiconductors [10] and metal-doped, noble metals-doped catalysts [11] have been explored as potential photocatalysts. However, the low photon utilization efficiency exhibited by these photocatalysts (only light with a certain wavelength may efficiently activate N2) and the facile excited electron-hole pairs still pose significant challenges in achieving high overall photocatalytic performance. For electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reactions (ENRR), H2O and N2 generate NH3 and O2 in the reaction process, which will not pollute the environment. At the same time, additional electricity from renewable sources of energy (including variables such as sunlight, wind power, tidal power, and hydropower) ought to be utilized to drive the drive and achieve rational use of energy. Additionally, ENRR avoids additional energy expenditure during storage and transit, making it more appropriate for distributed small-batch NH3 synthesis. In light of these, with a wide range of industrial applications, electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction has captured the extensive attention of numerous researchers. Given that no electrocatalyst that is effective in accelerating the chemical reactions has been generated, the ENRR field is still in its early stages. Even though a variety of relevant ENRR catalysts have been reported so far, the kinetics of most of them is very slow. Moreover, accurately quantifying ammonia production and the corresponding Faradaic efficiency (FE) in NRR remains challenging due to its low activity. There are two main problems in the NRR process, one is large overvoltage, and the other is that the selectivity and Faradaic efficiency of NRR are greatly reduced due to hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), especially in solution. Investigating effective and highly selective NRR electrocatalysts is therefore imperative. In this review, we systematically summarized the current status on the NRR systems, introducing some existing catalysts the of ENRR. Initially, in Section 2, fundamental principles of ENRR, the mechanism and anode and cathode reaction of ENRR are introduced in detail to show the intrinsic characteristics of ENRR. Secondly, experimental and theoretical researches on nitrogen reduction catalysts, especially in single-atom, dual-atom and nanoclusters are emphasized in Section 3. Finally, we summarized the future development trend and prospect of ENRR in Section 4, in which we examined the crucial elements that require being considered while creating promising catalysts of ENRR and proposed targeted solutions, anticipating that our viewpoint would be beneficial for the following research of ENRR system. 2 Fundamental principles of electrocatalytic NRR 2.1 Anode and cathode reaction of ENRR Five different kinds of electrolytic cells utilized in electrochemical ENRR research are depicted in Fig. 1 . Despite the simplicity of the device and ease of operation of single-chamber cells (Fig. 1a) and H-type cells (Fig. 1b), the gas-liquid-solid three-phase interface generated by direct contact between the catalyst and electrolyte triggers considerable competitive HER. Designing a catalyst with effective HER inhibition is the main goal of the project. Due to the solid-gas electrochemical reaction of the cathode, PEM cells (Fig. 1d) have superior ionic conductivity, whereas back-to-back cells (Fig. 1c) and PEM cells are physically favorable for preventing hydrogen evolution. The electrochemical flow cell shown in Fig. 1e is made up of a proton exchange membrane, an anode with or without GDL (gas diffusion layer), a cathode GDL and a flow electrolyte packed in two chambers. It is advantageous to introduce flow electrolyte in order to manage the reaction environment and encourage mass transfer [12]. Generally, the oxidation of H2O is performed at the anode, while NRR occurs at the cathode. The characteristics of the aqueous electrolyte determine the particular anode and cathode reactions. In an acidic electrolyte, NH3 molecules are created when protons generated by the anode are transferred directly to the cathode via a proton exchange membrane. The two half reactions that take place an acidic electrolyte are conveyed by formulas 2.1 and 2.2. Anode reaction (oxidation reaction) (2.1) 2 H 2 O → 4 H + + O 2 + 4 e − Cathode reaction (reduction reaction) (2.2) 6 H + + N 2 + 6 e − → 2 N H 3 In an alkaline electrolyte, N2 combines with H2O and electrons on the cathode to form NH3 and OH−, which are then transferred to the anode through an anion exchange membrane and oxidized to O2. The two half reactions that occur in an alkaline electrolyte are represented by formulas 2.3 and 2.4. Anode reaction (oxidation reaction) (2.3) 4 O H − → 2 H 2 O + O 2 + 4 e − Cathode reaction (reduction reaction) (2.4) N 2 + 6 H 2 O + 6 e − → 2 N H 3 + 6 O H − Formula 2.5 can be employed to indicate the overall reaction in both types of electrolytes. (2.5) 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O → 4 N H 3 + 3 O 2 2.2 Mechanism of selective catalytic reduction of NH3 Several potential processes for the catalytic surface conversion of N2 to NH3 have been revealed by theoretical investigations, mainly including the dissociative pathway, the associative pathway, the Mars–van Krevelen (MvK) pathway and enzymatic pathway [13]. In the dissociation pathway (Fig. 3a), the NN triple bond breaks before hydrogenation, allowing two separate N to attach to the catalyst surface, followed by separate hydrogenation to produce NH3. In this process, the breaking of the NN triple bond generally requires very high energy consumption. Kordali [14] observed that during the electrochemical ammonia synthesis process, 14N2 and 15N2 isotopes were disrupted into a mixed 14N15N at normal pressure and low temperature on a Ru cathode using a solid polymer electrolyte battery (SPE), indicating that the NN bond was decomposed into atomic N* before hydrogenation. Therefore, the NRR mechanism of this catalyst is the dissociation pathway. In contrast, the two nitrogen atoms in the associative pathway remain bonded until the first NH3 molecule is released with hydrogenation and the NN bond is completely broken. The associative distal pathway and the associative alternating pathway are two subtypes of the associative pathway. In the associative distal pathway (Fig. 3b), protonation first occurs on the terminal N atom until the first NH3 molecule is released. Subsequently, the second NH3 molecule is created by a hydrogenation process on the N atom adsorbed on the catalyst. In the associative alternating pathway (Fig. 3c), the hydrogenation reaction alternates between the terminal N atom and the proximal N proton prior to the dissociation of the NN bond. For example, Wang et al. [15] have designed a graphene-supported MoO2 material (MoO2/RGO). Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the rate determining step (RDS) is the first protonation of N2, with the highest energy barrier of 1.05 eV. Therefore, the NRR mechanism of the catalyst is the associative distal pathway (Fig. 2 a). Li et al. [16] developed a VB monolayer catalyst that follows an associative alternating pathway in ENRR. DFT calculations revealed that the RDS is the alternating protonation of *N2 (Fig. 2b), with a low onset potential of −0.396 V. The reaction steps perfectly match the standard alternating pathway ( N 2 → * N 2 H → * HNNH → * H 2 NNH ), further confirming the mechanism type. Isotope labeling (15N2) and in situ electrochemical microscopy experiments corroborated the dynamic process of alternating nitrogen atom protonation. Furthermore, combining both theoretical calculations and experiments, Bao et al. [17] employed tetrahexahedral gold nanorods (THH Au NRs) that simultaneously detected NH₃ (1.648 μg h-1 cm-2) and N2H4·H2O (0.102 μg h-1 cm-2) at −0.2 V vs. RHE. In accordance with the theoretically predicted distribution of the alternate path intermediates (Fig. 2c), the experimentally determined yield ratio of NH3 to N2H4·H2O was 16:1. The team of Murmu [18] has revealed the NRR catalytic mechanism of nickel phthalocyanine (NiPc) based on DFT simulations. The calculation showed that the key transition state is N 2 → NNH , corresponding to an energy barrier of 1.22 eV. The generation of the NHNH intermediate (ΔG=−0.28 eV) is significantly better than that of the NHNH2 path (ΔG=+0.44 eV), which conforms to the typical characteristics of the alternating pathway. Abghoui and Skúlason proposed a Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) pathway [19] specifically designed for electrochemical nitrogen reduction processes using transition metal nitrides as catalysts (Fig. 3 d). In contrast to the traditional dissociative and associative pathways, the MvK pathway allows for the continual hydrogenation and reduction of the TMN catalysts' surface lattice nitrogen to NH3 molecules, which creates an N-vacancy. The N-vacancy is replenished by N2 dissolved in the electrolyte, and another surface N atom is then reduced to produce a second NH3 to complete the catalytic cycle. The MvK mechanism predicts a lower overpotential for N2 reduction and NH3 production than the associative mechanism [20]. Furthermore, two N atoms in nitrogen bind to surface of the catalyst independently rather than in the remote adsorption mode on biological nitrogenases and certain catalysts with a strong nitrogen binding capacity, hydrogenating in a process known as the enzymatic pathway (Fig. 3e). Wang et al. [21] synthesized the bimetallic material Fe1.89Mo4.11O7/FeS2@C by hydrothermal method using PMo12@MIL-100 (Fe) @PVP as the precursor. DFT calculations indicated that the first step of hydrogenation was the rate-limiting step (0.61 eV), which was much higher than N2 adsorption and other protonation steps. The NRR reaction mechanism of Fe1.89Mo4.11O7/FeS2@C is enzymatic pathway. 3 Classification and characteristics of nitrogen reduction electrocatalysts 3.1 SACs A family of catalysts known as single-atom catalysts (SACs) are uniformly distributed as single atoms on the substrate [22,23]. Compared with traditional carrier catalysts /bulk catalysts, the benefits of SACs include high metal utilization efficiency, high activity, and notable reaction selectivity. In addition, the SACs can also reduce the occurrence of side reactions and improve the selectivity of reactions [5,24,25]. To fully reflect the current research status of the catalysts, Table 1 presents representative SACs for ambient electrocatalytic NRR. Transition metal catalysts have been widely used in electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis because of their excellent electrical conductivity, which helps to accelerate electron transfer in electrochemical systems [59]. Transition metal SACs of ENRR have the advantages of both monatom and transition metal in catalysts. Currently, relevant ENRR SACs reported mainly include: (1) noble metal-based SACs (2) non-noble metal-based SACs. 3.1.1 Noble metal-based SACs Density functional theory calculations and experimental results have shown that precious metals (such as Au, Ag, Ru, Rh, Pd, etc.) have potential electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction properties. Gold: In an aqueous solution of sulfuric acid, Wang et al. [60] reported atomically scattered Au on carbon nitride (Au1/C3N4) and examined its efficiency towards N2 reduction to NH4 +. Au1/C3N4 demonstrated exceptional NH4 + production, reaching 11.1 % at −0.2 V vs. RHE (versus reversible hydrogen electrode). Effective atom utilization has led to yield rate of 1305 μg mgAu -1 h-1 for NH4 +, which is about 22.5 times greater than that of supported Au nanoparticles. Furthermore, high catalytic performance was demonstrated by AuSAs-NDPCs, which are single Au-atom catalysts supported on N-doped carbons. In 0.1 M HCl, Qin et al. [26] showed that AuSAs-NDPCs had the NH3 yields of 2.32 μg h-1 cm−2 and an FE of 12.3 % at −0.2 V vs. RHE. Notably, the sophisticated Co3Mo3N catalyst in the commercial Haber-Bosch process has an activation energy of 57 kJ mol−1, whereas this catalyst's is merely 12.3 kJ mol−1. Chen et al. [28] separated Au into np-MoSe2, and the synthesized AuSA/np-MoSe2 yielded 30.83 µg h −1 mg−1 and FE of 37.82 % at −0.3 V vs. RHE in 0.1 m Na2SO4 under ambient conditions. The cyclic test also proved its good stability. Through a simple deposition method, Sun et al. [29] prepared Au single atoms anchored to porous β-FeOOH nanotubes. With NH3 yields of up to 2860 µgh-1mgAu -1 at −0.4 V vs. RHE and a FE of 14.2 %, the resultant Au-SA/FeOOH can effectively accelerate the NRR, outperforming all previously documented gold-based electrocatalysts. Silver: Chen and colleagues focused on admolecules and successfully created massively single Ag sites with Ag-N4 coordination. Under ambient conditions, these sites demonstrate an exceptional NH3 yield rate (270.9 μg h−1mgcat. −1) and FE (21.9 %) in HCl. According to their study, the secret to high-performance NRR is the successive formation of oblique end-on*NNH and vertical end-on*N2 admolecules on single metal sites, as determined by first-principles calculations [30]. Ruthenium: N2 electrolysis of reduction over Ru single atoms dispersed on nitrogen-doped carbon (Ru SAs/NC) exhibited an unprecedented level of performance, which generated ammonia with a partial current density of −0.13 mA cm-2 was reported by Geng et al. in 2018. Ru SAs/NC possessed a greater partial current density for NH3 production than Ru NPs/NC at all applied potentials (Fig. 4 a), and a FE of 29.6 % at −0.2 V vs. RHE, which is 2.1 times that of Ru NPs/NC (Fig. 4b). Remarkably, the Ru SAs/NC yield rate reachd 120.9 μgNH3 h-1mgcat. −1 (Fig. 4c), an order of magnitude greater than the greatest value ever recorded. A 12-hour durability test demonstrated the catalyst's excellent durability as well (Fig. 4d) [31]. It has been verified that the production of NH3 does not result from the self-electrolysis of the catalyst. The 1H NMR (nuclear magnetic resonance) spectroscopy detected 15NH4 + generated from the reduction of 15N2, thus confirming that the NH3 produced over the catalyst indeed originates from the electrochemical reduction of N2. Considering that dual-site collaboration boosts ENRR, Yang and colleagues developed a ruthenium-sulfur-carbon (Ru-S-C) catalyst, where the Ru metal center and its adjacent sulfur atom worked together to efficiently carry out ENRR under ambient conditions. During the experiment, they employed 1H NMR spectroscopy (operating at 500 MHz) to analyze the electrolyte after treating it with ENRR using 14N2 and 15N2 as nitrogen sources. The results, confirmed by 15N2 isotope labeling, demonstrated that all detected ammonia originated solely from the ENRR process, excluding any contamination or experimental errors (Fig. 5 a). At all applied potentials, Ru‐S‐C catalyst achieved a considerably higher FE compared to a Ru-nitrogen-carbon (Fig. 5b). Furthermore, at −0.15 V vs. RHE, the Ru‐S‐C catalyst yielded 13.18 μg h-1mgcat. −1 for NH3, which is almost twice that of the Ru‐N‐C catalyst (Fig. 5c), and Ru‐N‐C exhibited an inferior partial ENRR current density than Ru‐S‐C (inset of Fig. 5c). The turnover frequency (TOF) of Ru-S-C was 20 s–1 at −0.15 V vs. RHE, as illustrated in Fig. 5d, indicating a high activity that is more than twice that of Ru‐N-C (9 s–1) [32]. Additionally, a variety of materials are capable of supporting a single Ru atom. Cao et al. [61], for instance, provided several models using density functional theory. These carbon-based substances include Ru1@C2N, Ru1@T-C3N4, and Ru1@γ-graphyne (the limiting potentials were −0.96, −0.94, and −0.98 V, respectively) are part of a new family of exceptionally efficient NRR electrocatalysts. In experiment, Han et al. [33] a preparation method for porous carbon (PC) featuring a 5,7-membered carbon ring structure, aiming to embed single-atom Ru within the PCs. An ammonia yield rate of up to 67.8 ± 4.9 μg h–1 mgcat –1 and FE of 19.5 ± 0.6 % at −0.6 V vs. RHE demonstrated the remarkably promising catalytic NRR capabilities of these materials as electrocatalysts. With a hydrogen radical-transferring mechanism, Feng et al. [62] designed ruthenium single atoms anchored on graphdiyne/graphene sandwich structures (Ru SAs/GDY/G). The experiments were conducted in a custom-made H-cell separated by a Nafion 117 membrane, and the synthesized ammonia was quantitatively analyzed using spectrophotometry and NMR spectroscopy, verifying the absence of NH3 and NOx contaminants in the thoroughly purified gases (14N2 and 15N2). In 0.5 M Na2SO4, the NH3 yield rate reached 56.8 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and the FE was 37.6 % at −0.1 V vs. RHE. Chen et al. [35] successfully constructed SA-Ru@rGO/NC(the single Ru atom anchored on a rGO/NC two-dimensional interface) electrocatalyst with the largest NH3 yield of 110.1 μg h−1 mgcat −1 and FE of 17.9 % at −0.3 V vs. RHE under ambient conditions. Rhodium: Stereo confinement-induced densely populated metal single atoms (Rh, Ru, Co) on graphdiyne (GDY) matrix were reported by Zou et al. [38]. In comparison to ambient conditions, the record-high NH3 yield rate of 74.15 μg h-1cm-2, the FE of 20.36 %, and the NH3 partial current of 0.35 mA cm−2 at −0.20 V vs. RHE were all demonstrated by the pressurized ENRR activity of Rh SA/GDY at 55 atm, which are 7.3 times, 4.9 times and 9.2 times higher than the ambient conditions, respectively. A time-independent ammonia yield rate using adequately cleaned 15N2 ensured the ammonia electrosynthesis from N2. Additionally, the newly developed catalysis system(Rh1/MnO2) has set a record with an impressive NH3 yield of 271.8 µg h⁻¹ mg⁻¹ and a FE reaching 73.3 %.The absence of NH3/NOx contaminants in purified gases were proved by the UV–vis and gas colorimetry [39]. Palladium: Despite the intrinsic superiority of precious metal Pd in adsorbing nitrogen molecules and breaking the high cleavage barrier of NN bonds notwithstanding, the excessively potent adsorption capacity hinders the desorption of the generated ammonia during ENRR, thereby significantly impeding the productivity of NH3. Guo et al. demonstrated that the hydrogen substituted graphene's high electron-density acetylene linkages can control the NH3 desorption and nitrogen adsorption on the active Pd sites, and the resulting Pd/HsGDY exhibited an NH3 yield of 11.59 µg cm-2 h-1 and an ultrahigh 44.45 % FE −0.25 V vs. RHE [40]. 3.1.2 Non-noble metal-based SACs Although the noble metal-based catalysts exhibit good activity for NRR, their broad application has been hampered by the rare and expensive nature of these noble metals. In addition to maximizing metal consumption, single transition metal atoms properly fixed on an appropriate substrate produce superior selectivity and exceptionally high catalytic efficiency for ENRR [63,64]. Many materials have been investigated for use as substrates [1]. Supported on 2D materials Two-dimensional (2D) materials are widely regarded as an exemplary new class of electrical catalyst supports, exhibiting robust stability, a high surface-to-volume ratio, tunable electronic structures, and other favorable properties. These attributes can enhance both the reaction rate and selectivity in catalytic processes. The application of certain newly predicted 2D materials, characterized by their high stability and exceptional conductivity, holds great promise as substrates for atomic metal catalysts in the field of electrocatalysis [65]. Graphene, the most promising 2D material, holds great promise as a platform for accommodating diverse individual metal atoms [66]. To attain maximum dispersion and stability, individual metal atoms are consistently anchored to graphene imperfections. In particular, a great deal of theoretical and experimental research has been done on SACs supported on nitrogen-doped graphene (NG). Many of them, such M1C3, M1C2N1, M1C3N1, M1N4, M1C4 (M represents the metal atom) and so on, have been successfully synthesized in the lab, with precise control over the coordination of the metal atoms [66–68]. Previous research has even indeed put forth universal synthetic approaches for obtaining N-doped graphene (N-G) supported SACs, such as M1CyN, which could be viewed as integrating the M1Nx moiety into the graphene structure, resulting in an active center similar to that of outstanding molecular NRR catalysts, like Fe-, Co-, and Mo-nitride complexes [69]. By employing first-principles calculations, Zhao et al. [70] also studied the stability of single metal atoms (M1) supported on N3-G. They examined the competitive adsorption of hydrogen and dinitrogen, as well as the potential competition between hydrogen adsorption on metal sites and the first protonation of dinitrogen. They identified Mo1/N3-G and Cr1/N3-G as potential electrocatalysts for NRR, the computationally expected overpotentials of which were 40 % (0.34 V) and 100 % (0.59 V), respectively, appearing to be promising electrocatalysts. Furthermore, the emerging electrocatalysts with atom supported on defective graphene offer an opportunity to investigate the structure-activity correlation in NRR. Zou et al. investigated the Nx-doped (x = 1, 2, 3) and single Fe atom implanted in single vacancy graphene for NRR. Substantial charge transfers, ranging from 0.66 to 0.97 electron charges (|e|), from the Fe atom to the substrate surfaces are observed in Fig. 6 a by Bader charge analysis. It is noteworthy that the coordination of the nearby N atom affected the magnetic moment of the Fe atom. There was an approximately linear relationship between the effective charge of an individual Fe atom and its magnetic moment, as depicted in Fig. 6b The Fe magnetic moment and the adsorption energy of N atom (^EN*) were found to scale almost linearly. A significantly lower overpotential for N2 electroreduction can be achieved by strengthening the DEN* and facilitating charge transfer between the N2 molecule and substrates owing to the enhanced magnetic moment of the Fe atom [71]. Graphyne (GY) is a new carbon isomer carried out up of sp2- and sp-hybridized C atoms, having excellent properties consisting of high conductivity, high specific surface area, and structural stability. It additionally possesses a linear structure and is lack of cis-anti-isomerism. In consequence of its distinctive structure, it serves as an auspicious substrate for metal atomic catalysts. For example, Song et al. systematically analyzed transition metal (TM) single-atom (Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Zr, Nb, and Mo) fixed to graphitic acetylene as NRR catalysts. The Eads values of the calculated end-on configuration were all negative (Fig. 7 a), demonstrating the efficient adsorption of N2 by the TM@GY catalyst through the end-on configuration. The side-on configuration was more favorable for N2 activation because the side-on configuration of all TM@GY catalysts had lower DG values than the end-on configuration except Mn@GY (Fig. 7b). Moreover, TM@GY (TM = Mn, Ti, Zr, Cr, Mo) catalyst had better selectivity for NRR than for HER (Fig. 7c). For the distal pathway, the minimum free energy barrier of the distal pathway was 0.36 eV (Fig. 7d). In contrast, a high DG of 0.64 eV needed to be overcome for the alternate pathway to form *NHNH (Fig. 7e). A similar study was conducted for V@GY, where the charge transfer of the former (0.45e) was higher than that of Mn@GY (0.34e), and the DG value of the first hydrogenation (*N2-*N2H) was lower than that of Mn@GY (0.36 eV) [72]. One study by He et al. [73] explored the potential of W@N-doped graphyne, which demonstrated remarkable catalytic activity for N2 reduction. Among the various coordination configurations, the W atom coordinated with a single N atom (doping into sp-hybridized carbon atoms) exhibited peak catalytic efficiency, showcasing an exceptionally low onset potential of 0.29 V. The distal catalytic pathway was determined to be the most efficient of the system. Additionally, compared to pristine graphyne, W@N-doped graphyne possessed higher conductivity, guaranteeing enhanced electron transfer effectiveness throughout the reduction process. Graphdiyne (GD or GDY), a carbon-based material featuring inherent uniform pores and triple bonds has captured significant interest due to its distinctive structural properties [74]. In the work of Han et al. [75], a sequence of single transition metal atoms anchoring on a monolayer graphdiyne (TM@GD, TM = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Nb, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, W, Ir, Pt, and Au) is screened by DFT calculations. Several TM@GD, including Ti@GD, V@GD, Nb@GD, Ru@GD, and W@GD, were calculated to have a comparatively smaller free energy upward for NRR compared to the Ru (0001) surface. Specifically, the Nb@GD was demonstrated to be the most excellent for NRR with a limited potential of only 0.27 V and a high selectivity of 49.95 %. Projected density of states (PDOS) analysis indicates significant hybridization between Nb 4d orbitals and C 2p orbitals of graphdiyne near the Fermi level, which constructs efficient electron transfer channels and enhances the stability of Nb anchoring (binding energy of 5.47 eV). Bader charge analysis shows that Nb donates over 1|e| to graphdiyne, rendering Nb positively charged to strengthen N2 adsorption, while charge density difference (CDD) analysis confirms bidirectional charge transfer between Nb and adsorbed N2: Electrons from Nb 4d orbitals populate the π antibonding orbitals of N2, while lone-pair electrons from N2 occupy vacant Nb d orbitals, thus establishing a donor-acceptor interaction that effectively activates N2. Very similarly, by employing first-principles calculations, Feng et al. designed a new class of SACs, namely graphdiyne coordinated single transition metal atoms (TM@GD, TM = Sc-Zn, Y-Cd and La-Hg), and analyzed their NRR catalytic properties. It is concluded that TM@GD (TM = Ti, V, Fe, Co, Zr, Rh and Hf) monolayers exhibited better NRR activity than Ru (0001) stepped surfaces. Among them, the most suitable candidate was V@GD monolayer, which had a minimal limit potential of −0.67 V in both alternating and distal processes [76]. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is the material that comes after graphene and graphyne in terms of suitability as a substrate for single-atom metal doping. Interfacial polarization, according to Zhang et al. [52], is an efficient strategy to boost NN cleavage and encourage the ENRR. Research have demonstrated that there corresponded to a significant electrostatic potential difference between SAC and N2 when sufficient EF is applied (Fig. 8 a). A quantitative analysis of the polarization field revealed a potential difference of 17.92 eV (Fig. 8b), greater than the N2 ionization potential of 15.84 eV. The authors further showed that, in the presence of a magnetic field, nearly 60 % of the electrons on SAC could be transported to the region between SAC and N2, favoring the breakdown of the N–N bond, while the remaining 36 % can be transferred to N–N (Fig. 8c). Due to the interfacial polarization, Fe-MoS2 could rapidly inject more electrons into the antibonding orbital of N2, which enabled the catalyst to exhibit excellent NRR activity, resulting in a high ammonia yield (36.1 ± 3.6 mmol g-1 h-1 or 97.5 ± 6 μg h-1 cm-2) at −0.20 V vs. RHE. A similar phenomenon applied to Co-MoS2, Cu-MoS2, Rh-MoS2, and Ru-MoS2. Other 2D materials, with their huge surface/volume ratio, also exhibit considerable potential as SAC substrates. For instance, as a robust two-dimensional material, MXene is composed of early transition metal carbides, nitrides and carbon nitrides, and has a variety of functions in batteries, including electrocatalysts, with excellent electrical conductivity and chemical stability [77,78]. SACs demonstrate promising characteristics as a synthesis ammonia electrocatalyst by embedding metal atoms into MXenes, showcasing their low cost, high efficiency, and environmentally friendly nature. After conducting a systematic study on SACs of three-dimensional transition metal M (including Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) embedded in the titanium defect site of Ti2CO2 (M1@Ti2CO2), Hu et al. [79] found that among the screened 3D transition metals, the V1@Ti2CO2 catalyst exhibited outstanding stability and demonstrated exceptional catalytic efficiency with a limiting potential as low as −0.20 V. Li et al. [64] introduced the descriptor ΔG*N to establish the limit potential volcanogram between different NRR intermediates, and found that TM@SiPV (TM = Mo, Nb, Ta, W), compared with the limit potential −0.87 V of defect SiP, had superior limit potential (−0.25, −0.45, −0.49 and −0.15 V, respectively). Notably, the N-doped carbon-based single-atom catalyst was additionally believed to be one of the important catalysts. Aided by density functional theory computations, Ling et al. screened the potential of single metal atoms (Cu, Pd, Pt, and Mo) loaded on N-doped carbon for NRR. It was discovered that Mo1 N1C2 could catalyze NRR by enzymatic mechanism with an ultralow overpotential of 0.24 V (Fig. 9 a), which is significantly lower than that of the ideal metal catalyst (well above 0.50 V [80]). Most importantly, the ΔG for NH3 desorption on Mo1 N1C2 was only 0.47 eV, giving Mo1 N1C2 excellent durability. The band structure and density of states (DOS) of Mo1 N1C2 (Fig. 9b) further indicated that Mo1 N1C2 has a strong metallicity and high conductivity [81]. As a substrate to anchor metal catalysts, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has numerous inherent advantages, which can effectively accumulate surface polarization charges on metal atoms and provide more accurate information for the identification of catalytic active sites. Chen et al. [82] assessed the NRR enzymatic performance of several kinds of individual transition metal atoms (Ti, Co, Mo, W etc.) supported on g-C3N4 based on these features. W@g-C3N4 exhibited the most remarkable activity towards NRR among these candidates, and its limiting potential was determined to be −0.35 V. The high activity of W@g-C3N4 is rooted in its electronic properties. PDOS analysis shows that before N2 adsorption, W-5d states have high peaks near the Fermi level, enabling rapid electron transfer. Subsequently, W-5d orbitals hybridize with N2–2p orbitals below the Fermi energy, arising from W (5dxz)-N2 (2px) and W (5dᵧz)-N2 (2pᵧ) coupling, corresponding to electron back-donation to activate N2. Bader charge analysis indicates W@g-C3N4 donates ∼0.62 electrons to adsorbed N2, accumulating negative charges to facilitate subsequent reductions. The deposition of single metal atoms on C2N monolayers as catalysts for a variety of processes has been theorized in numerous areas of research. For instance, Wang et al. [83] designed a new class of NRR electrocatalysts. A series of single transition metal atoms (Sc–Zn, Nb, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, and Ag) anchored on 2D C2N monolayer (TM@C2N) were extensively employed as heterogeneous catalysts and thoroughly examined as NRR electrocatalysts. In particular, the calculated NRR onset potential on Mo@C2N is −0.17 V, which is even lower than the −0.43 V for the widely recognized stepped Ru (0001) surface. As for the reported black phosphorus (BP) carrier single-atom catalysts, Zhao et al. [84] theoretically predicted the application prospect of P-ligands in NRR, taking into account the unique role of P-ligands in molecular complexes and the limitations of using original BP in electrocatalytic NRR. The calculation results showed that W@BP (0.40 eV), Ta@BP (0.47 eV) and Nb@BP (0.53 eV) had low reaction free energy, high stability and electrical conductivity. It had great potential in high efficiency electrocatalytic NRR. In particular, almost all metal centers had stronger adsorption capacity for *N2 intermediates than *H, which indicated that black phosphorus-hosted single-atom catalyst have strong NRR selectivity. 3d-, 4d- and 5d-SACs with monolayer black phosphorus as the substrate have also been extensively studied to electrocatalyze NRR. Investigation of Ou et al. [85] revealed that the novel single-atom catalysts of Hf1 N1P2–1 and Tc1 N4 exhibited good thermodynamic and electrochemical stability in BP substrates, with NRR overpotentials as low as 0.56 V and 0.49 V, respectively. Another article of his demonstrated that Mo-N complex supported on BP has the potential to enhance the catalytic activity of base surface nitrogen fixation under ambient conditions. With an overpotential of just 0.02 V and a free energy barrier of 0.56 eV, Mo1N3 exhibited exceptionally powerful electrocatalytic NRR activity, which was lower than that of the majority of NRR catalysts with documented low overpotential [86]. Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) sheet containing boron vacancy (VB) can also be used as the substrate supporting metal atoms, which has a broad application prospect in the field of NRR catalysis. Zhao et al. [87] made significant theoretical advances by conducting in-depth analyses of individual transition metal atoms (ranging from Sc to Zn, and including Mo etc.) on the surface of defective h-BN to assess the catalytic potential of these atoms in N2 fixation. The results showed that single Mo atom could exhibit excellent catalytic activity in the single vacancy formed by the absence of boron atom, and its catalytic system achieved an overpotential as low as 0.19 V through an enzymatic mechanism under ambient condition. It is noteworthy that boron monolayer, also known as borene, is a two-dimensional material consisting of boron atoms with a single atomic layer thickness. β12 phase is an allotrope of borene, and the natural porous structure of β12 and χ3 BM endows confers the β12-BM with significant potential for robustly anchoring individual metal atoms. By attaching a single transition-metal atom of the first and second transition series on the β12 phase of the boron monolayer, Zhu et al. created a novel kind of electrocatalyst that is inexpensive, highly stable, selective, and efficient in moderate conditions. According to their findings, end-on patterns were more energy-favorable than side-on patterns for the same transition metal atom. Only V/β12-BM and Mn/β12-BM exhibited spontaneous adsorption of N2 (due to ΔGN2 < 0 eV) for the side-on patterns (Fig. 10 a). Consequently, the interaction between N2 and TM/β12-BM was elucidated by the difference of N2 adsorbed charge density in the two systems (Fig. 10c and Fig. 10d), which demonstrated that TM atom and N2 possessed a "acceptance−donation" interaction and that ionizing N2's 1π orbital are able to greatly lengthen the N − N bond, resulting in enhanced activity of N2 [88]. For transition metal single-atom catalysts, the d-band center position is intimately linked to N₂ adsorption energy and the energy barriers of reaction intermediates: when the d-band center approaches the Fermi level, the π-backbonding between the metal and N₂ strengthens, facilitating NN bond activation, but excessively strong adsorption may hinder product desorption. Conversely, a lower d-band center may weaken N₂ adsorption. For instance, in the WS2-WO3 heterostructure constructed by Yan et al. [89], the d-band center of W significantly shifted upward to −0.72 eV, which is closer to the Fermi level compared with pure WS2 (−1.57 eV) and WO3 (−3.24 eV) (Fig. 10b). This upward-shifted d-band center enhances the adsorption of key intermediates such as *NH and *NH2 on the catalyst surface. The interaction between the active W site and the intermediate was enhanced, accelerating the protonation process of RDS and thereby improving the overall performance of ENRR. Its NH3 yield was 62.38 μg h-1mgcat. −1, and the FE was 24.24 %. It indicates that by rationally designing the catalyst to adjust the center of the d band to the optimal position, the adsorption of reactants and the desorption of products can be balanced. Borophene exhibits strong electrical and thermal conductivity, as well as great hardness, elasticity, flexibility, and chemical reactivity for reinforcing. In the work of Liu et al. [90], borophene-supported transition metals were screened for their potential as SACs. Under operating voltage conditions, TM@Bβ12 exhibits superior resistance to surface oxidation and inhibition of HER. In particular, the selected V@Bβ12, Cr@Bβ12, Zr@Bβ12 and Mo@Bβ12 exhibited strong selectivity in theoretical calculations, and the limiting potentials of NRR under the optimal path were −0.10, −0.27, −0.18 and −0.07 V, respectively. The excellent NRR catalytic activity of these TM@Bβ12 catalysts stems from the intrinsic electronic interactions and charge transfer mechanisms. PDOS analysis reveals significant hybridization between the d orbitals of transition metals (V, Cr, Zr, Mo) and the p orbitals of N2 near the Fermi level (Fig. 10e), which facilitates electron transfer from the metal to the antibonding π* orbitals of N2, thereby weakening the NN bond. Additionally, Hirshfeld charge analysis indicates that the highly electronegative borophene substrate acts as an electron donor, while the metal atoms serve as charge transmitters, which promote efficient charge transfer between the substrate and *NxHy intermediates. Reducible-oxide supported metals have driven advances in catalytic reaction research in recent years by virtue of their potent "electronic metal-support interaction" (EMSI). Xie and colleagues [45] employed VO2 , a two-dimensional substance with significant N2 adsorption capabilities, as a carrier to supply N2 while suppressing HER activity. Mo was presented as an active site for stimulating NRR given its significant NRR activity. Simultaneously, the electron-metal-carrier interaction between the carrier and Mo created an electron-deficient site, which lessened the H adsorption strength and lowered the energy barrier for the initial protonation process, thereby enhancing the NRR activity kinetically. At −0.5 V vs. RHE, Mo/VO2 showed excellent catalytic performance, which unfolded a high NH3 yield of 190.1 µgNH3 mgcat. −1 h−1 and an incredible FE value of 32.4 % at 0.05 M H2SO4, 10.8 and 2.8 times that of VO2, respectively. Supported on other supports. Non-noble metal-based SACs supported on other supports have emerged as a promising alternative in the field of electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction. These catalysts leverage the abundance and cost-effectiveness of non-noble metals, while utilizing various support materials to enhance the stability, activity, and selectivity of the catalysts. For instance, Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a type of porous crystalline structure composed up of organic ligands and metal clusters or ions [46,91–94], which, because of their structural regularity and synthetic tunability, have been shown to be the excellent precursors or templates for pyrolyzing SACs with enhanced metal loading [91]. Until recently, electrocatalytic N2 fixation has been used to create a few monometallic MOFs, including Fe, Cu, Co, Al, Zr, Ce, and In, for NH3 production. Zhao and co-workers [46] initially reported MOFs as NRR catalysts in 2017, in which the MOFs (MOF(Fe), MOF(Co) and MOF(Cu)) have been generated utilizing a hydrothermal method. With the maximum ammonia production rate and current efficiency of 2.12 × 10−9 mol s −1 cm−2 and 1.43 %, respectively, the MOF(Fe) demonstrated the most effective catalytic capability. Additionally, the most popular classic MOF, HKUST-1, was employed to produce NH3 electrochemically. The rate of synthesizing ammonia reached 46.63 μg h-1 mgcat. −1and the FE was 2.45 % [95]. Under mild conditions, d-orbital transition metal-based MOFs hold promise as electrocatalysts for the electrochemical production of ammonia. Motivated by the NRR performance of some potential electrocatalysts (such as NH2−MIL-88B-Fe and MIL88B-Fe [96]), the ecologically conscious synthesis of NH3 was carried out employing MOFs based on Cu and Co. He and colleagues have recently unveiled a defective Zirconium-based metal-organic framework (UiO-66-NH2) characterized by reliable O2, which effectively catalyzed ENRR in 0.1 M Na2SO4, and the NH3 yield was as high as 2.071 × 10–10 mol s-1 cm-2 and the FE value was up to 85.21 % at −0.39 V vs. RHE [47]. Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that the main-group elements, such as Bi, B, and Al [97], are efficient NRR catalysts. The p orbitals of main group elements tend to have a stronger coupling with the N 2p orbitals of N2 than the d-orbital transition metals, which suppresses HER. Examples include MIL-100(Al), an AL-based MOF containing hybrid hypertetrahedra, was initially created by Fu et al. [98] to transform N2 to NH3 in 0.1 M KOH media. NH3 production and FE were at their maximum were 10.6 μg h-1 mgcat. −1and 22.6 % at 177 mV vs. RHE. 3.1.3 Metal-free SACs To this point, metal-based single-atom catalysts demonstrate superior electrocatalytic activity in NRR. Nonetheless, these catalysts are not without their inherent limitations, which include (1) the pronounced adsorption of hydrogen and (2) the potential leaching of metal atoms. It's fortunate that metal-free electrocatalysts have garnered significant and growing attention for a wide array of electrochemical processes, thanks to their cost-effectiveness, tunable composition, robustness at high temperatures, eco-friendliness, non-corrosive characteristics, and distinctive physical and chemical properties [99–103]. Among them, B is one of the most excellent monatomic catalysts. A groundbreaking work has found that boron atoms have catalytic activity to reduce N2, opening a new door for metal-free catalysts for NRR [2]. By means of extensive DFT, Ji and colleagues conducted research demonstrating that a boron-interstitial (Bint)-doped C2N sheet can function as a metal-free electrocatalyst for the fixation and reduction of N2 to NH3. The calculations showed that the Bint-doped C2N layer adequately activated the N2 molecule by means of the "acceptance-donation" mechanism. Specifically, the subsequent nitrogen reduction reaction tended to occur through an enzymatic pathway with a notably low limiting potential of 0.15 V, indicating its high catalytic efficiency for nitrogen reduction [102]. Using first-principles calculations, the B decorated C9N4 monolayer (B-C9N4) for NRR is investigated. It is discovered that the electron "acceptance-donation" pattern between N2 and the B dopant may adequately activate the inert N2. With an overpotential of 0.56 V, the reduction of *N2 to *N2H is the potential-limiting phase, and the following N2 reduction favors the alternating process [104]. Shi et al. [103] has developed a metal-free electrocatalyst, which utilizes boron-doped black phosphorus, inspired by the “Lewis acid pair” strategy to minimize redundancy. Assessment of the catalyst's performance revealed that this metal-free electrocatalyst is highly effective for the electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (ENRR), exhibiting an exceptionally low onset potential of 0.19 V. Zheng et al. [105] utilized DFT to explore the feasibility of single-boron catalysts on MXene supports for NRR electrocatalysis. The most promising alternatives with high catalytic efficiency and selectivity are identified as B-doped Mo2CO2 and W2CO2, whose limiting potentials for NRR are just −0.20 and −0.24 V, respectively. One essential step in promoting electrochemical NRR is the adsorption of N2 molecules. The NRR catalyst GDY monolayer is ineffective because of the estimated adsorption energy of −0.07 eV, accompanied by a separation of 2.97 Å between the N2 molecule and the unmodified GDY surface, as well as an NN bond length of 1.11 Å, identical to that of a standalone N2 molecule. In order to investigate the NRR properties of single-heteroatom-doped GDY monolayers, Feng et al. selected three nonmetallic elements (B, N and O) to obtain single atom doped GDY monolayers. According to the calculated formation energies of various doped GDY, B preferred to replace the Cb atom (X-b GDY), whereas N and O preferred to replace the C1 atom (X-1 GDY) (Fig. 11 a-d). Afterwards, utilizing various configurations and adsorption sites, N2 adsorption was evaluated on several optimized doped GDY surfaces. Fig. 11e depicted the nitrogen adsorption state on oxygen-doped GDY, wherein the nitrogen atoms are adsorbed in an end-pair mode. Additional analysis of charge density differences using Bader charge analysis revealed a transfer of 0.41 e from the O-doped GDY to the N2 molecule. (Fig. 11f), which illustrating that the inert NN triple bonds could be activated on O-doped GDY catalyst [101]. 3.2 DACs Although SACs have the advantage of high atomic utilization, they also have some limitations in practical applications [25]. For example, individual metal atoms may easily polymerize or migrate during the reaction, resulting in loss of the active site and degradation of catalyst performance. In addition, SACs may not be as effective as expected when dealing with multistep reactions or complex reactions that require synergies of multiple active sites. Given these shortcomings, Dual-atom catalysts (DACs) offer a solution. DACs show special advantages, including: 1) the utilization rate of plat; 2) Excellent catalytic performance; 3) Interatomic synergies. Although the common view that diatomic catalysts are superior to single-atom catalysts is not always correct (the reaction intermediates are over-stable, resulting in product barriers) [106], DACs break the scale of the synergistic relationship between binding energy and reaction intermediates through the mutual support of two atoms to a certain extent, making it have a broader space for development [107]. Table 2 summarizes some dual-atom nitrogen reduction electrocatalysts and their key metrics. 3.2.1 Homonuclear DACs Homonuclear diatomic catalysts consist of two identical atoms that are adjacent in space to form an active site with a specific geometry. Due to the strong interaction between homonuclear metal atoms, homonuclear DACs exhibit excellent performance in some catalytic reactions. For example, Zhang et al. [121] decorated graphene with four neighboring nitro nitrogen atoms after inserting two homonuclear transition metal atoms (TM2N4@graphene) to calculate and examine the performance metrics of 15 homonuclear DACs, pinpointing Fe2N4@graphene as the top-performing NRR catalyst with a reduced limiting potential to −0.32 V (Fig. 12 a). Simultaneously, CN-based DACs is also the focus of research. By employing first-principles calculations, Liang et al. [123] examined the possibility of using various 3d transition metal dimers as catalysts in the NRR. After preliminary screening, it was found that Fe and Co homonuclear metal dimers fixed on nitrogen-containing graphene selectively adsorbed and activated N2 compared with water energy. Subsequently, the nitrogen reduction reaction pathways and Gibbs free energy diagrams of reactions on FeFe@NC and CoCo@NC were investigated in detail. The limiting potentials of these catalysts were −0.44 V and −0.45 V respectively, better than those of multi-catalysts. Compared with metal-based catalysts, they can inhibit the hydrogen evolution reaction well, and their cyclicity and durability were also verified. In addition, Biswas et al. [124] developed a catalyst design strategy for efficient conversion of nitrogen to ammonia, successfully anchoring Al-Al diatomic site on nitrogen-doped porous carbon (Al2NC), and achieving a yield of 29.22±1.2 µg.h-1. mgcat -1 and FE of 16.56±0.3 % at −0.60 V vs. RHE. Zhang et al. [122] reported the catalytic performance of transition metal atom-anchored C2N monolayer electrocatalysts for nitrogen fixation (TMx@C2N, x = 1 or 2; TM=Ti, Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Ir, Pt or Au). The adsorption of DG by N2 around the TM atom on TMx@C2N was calculated, and the findings are presented in Fig. 12b-Fig. 12c. The adsorption of DG for N2 was positive on Pd2@C2N, Ag1@C2N, Pt2@C2N and Au1@C2N, but extremely low (−0.03 eV) on Mn1@C2N, indicating that they had poor adsorption of N2 and are not suitable for fixing N2. The remaining TM atoms were further studied (calculated the adsorption DG (TMx@C2N) of N2 by M atom and the adsorption energies of intermediates (N2H and NH2), etc.). Among them, Mo2@C2N showed the highest efficiency in catalyzing the conversion of N2 to NH3, with a peak free energy transformation of 0.41 eV and an energy hurdle of 0.51 eV. In addition, single boron doped two-dimensional material is an effective NRR electrocatalyst, and double boron doped two-dimensional graphene-like carbon nitride (C2N-h2D) electrocatalyst (B2@C2N) has good catalytic performance in theoretical calculation as well. Cao et al. [125] used DFT calculations to demonstrate that both single and double boron atoms could be effectively embedded in natural nanopore C2N and showed excellent catalytic activity for N2 activation. Compared with B@C2N (0.29 eV), B2@C2N is a more efficient NRR electrocatalyst with lower overpotential (0.19 eV). Throughout the reaction, the GDY catalytic substrate may effectively accommodate double atoms in its acetylenic ring, hence promoting the electronic nature of the primary catalytic site. Ma et al. [126] theoretically conducted a comprehensive study on the NRR catalytic activity of graphdiyne monolayers anchored by transition metals (TM, such as Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni). When compared to the Ru (0001) stepped surface, it is demonstrated that the majority of TM monomer- and dimer-anchored GDY monolayers exhibited well catalytic efficacy in NRR. With an onset potential of −0.43 V and a strong ability to suppress HER, Co2@GDY especially owned the strongest NRR catalytic activity. The remarkable NRR catalytic function of the Co2@GDY may have been caused by the confined electronic states close to the Fermi level and the strong electron-donating ability of the GDY monolayer. Homonuclear and heteronuclear diatomic (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo) anchored GDY complexes were assessed by Jasin Arachchige [127]. One of the most promising NRR catalysts is the Mo2@GDY complex, which had a maximum energy input of 0.61 eV through the continuous reaction mechanism among the 15 catalytic systems examined. Furthermore, bimetallic atoms-doped nanomaterial catalysts have received extensive attention. As a group III-V nanomaterial, boron nitride nanotubes (BNNTs) offer advantages for surface catalytic reactions due to their unique physical and chemical properties. The concept of BNNT was first predicted theoretically in 1994 [128], and subsequently synthesized experimentally by Zettl and other researchers in 1995 [129]. On this basis, Liu et al. [130] studied TM/BNNT and constructed DACs and TM1TM2/BNNT models. In these models, the limiting potential of FeFe/BNNT and MnMn/BNNT reached −0.17 and −0.58 V, respectively. After comprehensive analysis and evaluation, FeFe/BNNT is considered to be the most promising candidate. Recent researches have also unequivocally affirmed the exceptional catalytic efficiency of borophene in the realm of ENRR. Rao et al. [131] conducted a comprehensive study on the possibility of using 2D borophene-backed transition metals as bimetallic atomic catalysts (BACs) for the ENRR. Sc2B12, Ti2B12, V2B12, and Zr2B12 underwent progressive screening and were found to be viable ENRR catalysts by using an energy-oriented screening mechanism. Further analysis yielded their whole chemical pathways and Gibbs free energy (ΔG), along with the appropriate overpotentials, which revealed that the overpotentials of catalysts for their potential determining stages (PDS) were 0.34, 0.40, 0.39, and 0.13 V, respectively. Cu2B12 has exceptional performance for HER at a low 0.05 V overpotential. In contrast to the experimentally recorded values of −0.73 and −0.98 V for the Ru-based single-atom catalyst and Ru (0001) stepped surface, Rasool [132] found that Fe2, Co2, and W2 dimer species impregnated in a tetracyanoquinodimethane-based monolayer achieved suitable adsorption behavior for numerous NRR intermediates. The results illustrated very low limiting potential values of −0.56, −0.58, and −0.53 V for Fe2,Co2, and W2, respectively. Meanwhile, Le et al. [133] concluded that an array of transition metal dimers (TM2) loaded on poly triazine imide (PTI) had good stability by means of density functional theory calculations. With a favorable limiting potential of −0.53, −0.36, and −0.63 V, respectively, Mo2@PTI, Re2@PTI, and Pt2@PTI effectively diminished HER and can be utilized as effective electrocatalysts for NRR. 3.2.2 Heteronuclear DACs Heteronuclear DACs are composed of two different metal atoms, and the diversity of atoms gives them more means of regulation in catalytic reactions [134]. The varied electronic configurations and electron affinities of heteronuclear DACs facilitate improved regulation of electron transfer in NRR, while synergistic effects are the main factor in improving the catalytic activity of various reactions, thereby improving the performance of catalysts [109,135]. Previous studies [136] have shown that strong d-d orbital coupling can occur between copper (Cu) and palladium (Pd), which can improve the efficiency of electron transport and thus achieve excellent catalytic performance in NRR. Han et al. [108] precisely modulated a single palladium atomic site on a nitrogen-doped carbon material (PdCu/NC) and constructed a diatomic Pd-Cu site. The material exhibited a high FE of 24.8 ± 0.8 % and the NH3 yield rate of 69.2 ± 2.5 μg h-1 mgcat. −1, which could be achieved at a potential of −0.45 V vs. RHE in a 0.05 M H2SO4. It was 14.6 times and 4.2 times that of pure palladium catalyst (Pd/NC) (Fig. 13 a-b). In addition, the theoretical results supported that the introduction of Cu into Pd/NC reduced the energy required for the PDS of NRR, thereby enhancing the selectivity of the reaction. Coincidentally, Wang et al. [109] carried out a computational analysis of various M/Fe pairs (where M includes Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Co, and Ni), suggesting a bimetallic V/Fe catalyst with individual atoms dispersed on a nitrogen-doped carbon matrix (VFe/NC). In this structure, the V 3dz2 orbitals “pushed” electrons into the antibonding states of adsorbed N2, while the Fe 3dyz orbitals “pulled” extra electrons back. Leveraging the cooperative action of the twin active centers, the NH3 yield rate reached 73.44 μg h-1 mgcat. −1 and the FE reached 43 % at a potential of −0.1 V vs. RHE (Fig. 13c-d), surpassing the atomic level of the corresponding catalyst reported in the literature. The research of Jiang et al. [137] also showed that the synergistic effects in VFe-N-C, VMn-N-C, and MoMn-N-C systems primarily stem from complementary electronic structures of dual transition metals and regulated adsorption configurations. Taking VFe-N-C as an example, the higher d-band center of V induces electron transfer to Fe, forming a charge gradient. This enhances V accepting electrons from N2 3σ orbital and Fe back-donating electrons to N2 π* antibonding orbitals, effectively activating NN bond (bond length elongated 0.114 Å). The dual sites enable N2 to adsorb strongly in a side-on mode while allowing NH2* to bind weakly in an end-on configuration, breaking the linear scaling relationship (LSR) that limits single-atom catalysts. In addition, Liu and colleagues [138] designed dual-metal-free atoms anchored on g-CN. The theoretical calculation results indicated that B-P@g-CN, which had a limit potential of −0.18 V.The excellent NRR activity of B-P@g-CN stems from the "σ donation -π feedback" process of the metal-N2 reaction, which is due to the fact that B and P have empty sp2 and sp3 orbitals, and their strong and weak adsorption capabilities hybridize, thereby causing a synergistic effect between them. Ma et al. [139] designed a novel heteronuclear diatomic electrocatalyst FeV@C2N, which is co-doped with Fe and V, improving the kinetic properties of NRR and inhibit HER. The nitrogen-containing pore structure in C2N was able to effectively anchor the Fe and V atoms, while the unoccupied/occupied d orbitals of the Fe and V atoms were able to accept/provide electrons from/to N2 (Fig. 13e). Thus, Fe and V atoms existed stably on the C2N matrix and act as active sites to catalyze the NRR. FeV@C2N could effectively weaken the NN and increased the Bader charge difference of N atom by chemisorbed adsorption, resulting in stronger N2 activation ability than Fe2@C2N and V2@C2N (Fig. 13f-h). In atomically scattered catalysts, both single TM anchored SAC and double TM anchored DAC revealed strong thermodynamic stability. For example, Qian et al. [140] selected single-anchored Sc, Y, La, Ti, Zr, Hf SACs and double-anchored Cr and V DACs as the promising NRR catalysts. In the case of atomic dispersion, IVB metals (Ti, Zr, Hf) revealed the highest reactivity and the lowest overpotential. Furthermore, CoNi@GDY was presented in Arachchige's paper through a distal reaction mechanism at maximal energy inputs of just 0.52 eV [127]. In DACs, the Cr-Cr system generated NH3, and the V-V system generated N2H4. A new π-donor/π-reverse N2 molecular activation mechanism with defective boron nitride supported cage diatomic catalyst was found. In the part of non-noble metal-based SACs, it was mentioned that different single transition metal atoms (such as Mo) on the hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) monolayer of defects have excellent catalytic capacity for nitrogen fixation. On this basis, Cao et al. [141] studied cage diatomic catalysts supported by defective boron nitride (TM1-TM2@VB-BN). Ru-Ti@VB-BN was selected as the ideal candidate, whose limiting potential was −0.40 V. Compared with the corresponding single-atom catalyst, the introduction of Ti/Mo regulated the d-band center of the active metal atoms, thereby improving the catalytic capacity. However, h-BN showed a mixed-blessing broad band gap that facilitated the accumulation of excited electrons and holes; yet, its low conductivity made it unsuitable for the use of electrocatalysts. Graphene, on the other hand, has a band gap but good electrical conductivity. Given their comparable crystal structures, the advantages of the two can be fused by constructing the h-BN -graphene hybrid substrate through interface engineering. By using DFT calculations, Zhou et al. [142] predicted that rhenium (Re) and osmium (Os) diatomic catalysts anchored at the boundary of the h-BN-graphene interface have excellent NRR catalytic properties, showing very low limit potentials of 0.29 V and 0.33 V respectively. Additionally, they found the synergy of the h-BN-graphene, including rich accumulation and unique electronic distribution and optimization of energy band structure. In particular, the application of the synergistic effect of the h-BN and graphene interface to diatomic catalysts, such as Fe-Mo@h-BN, achieved an exceptionally low limit potential of 0.17 V, further demonstrating the potential of interface effects in improving the performance of diatomic catalysts. Heteronuclear DACs loaded on other substrates also exhibited unique advantages. For example, in the work of Jia et al. [143], ten stable heteronuclear diatomic catalysts supported by graphene doped with nitrogen were developed, and Ti–Mo, Ti–W, Mo–W, V–Cr, Mo–Cr, and W–Cr were identified as promising candidates. With the lowest overpotential of 0.45 V, the MoCrN6-G catalyst demonstrated high thermodynamic stability and inhibitory effects on the HER. Furthermore, given its low desorption free energy of 0.15 eV, NH3 readily separated from the catalyst surface, creating new active sites promptly. Among the eight graphene-supported diatomic Fe-based catalysts that Yang et al. [144] built, they screened out FeTi-GS with a limiting potential of −0.88 V. PdNb-BP, a heteronuclear diatomic catalyst suggested by Zhang et al. [145], demonstrated both significant NRR catalytic activity and a low desorption free energy of 0.17 eV for NH3. Wu et al. [146] also examined the free energy changes of the essential NRR steps on 55 diatomic structures, collecting the essential characteristics and obtaining 5 structures that are appropriate for NRR through screening (substrate=black phosphorus, atomic combination = TiV, TiCo, VCr, VCo, and VNi). Gao and colleagues [147] examined the NRR catalytic performance of thirty Fe-based dual-atom catalysts and suggested that Fe/Mo-N-C can enhance the reaction by controlling atomic spin. In order to verify the application of synergies in FeMoN5O1, Liu et al. [148] further designed a series of heteronuclear DACs FeMoN6-aXa (a = 1,2,3; X = B, C, O, S), which was achieved by controlling the atomic coordination environment of the FeMo dimer anchored to the hole of g-C3N4. Su et al. [149] calculated and evaluated transition metal dimers (TM1TM2/N6–1, TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Mo) anchored to nitrogen-doped graphene. 16 promising DACs exhibited low limiting potential (−0.09 V to −0.85 V) and high selectivity for NRR, and ScMo/N6–1 has an ultra-low limit potential of −0.09 V and 100 % FE. The problems of selectivity and biological catalytic reduction reaction activity in nitrogen atoms scattered catalyst need to be solved. Using 2D phthalocyanine (Pc) as a carrier, Guo et al. [63] created a comparative map of the stability, activity, and selectivity of metal dimers, which included heteronuclear (MM'-Pc) and homonuclear (M2-Pc) diatomic catalysts. Calculations showed that 3 homonuclear DACs and 28 heteronuclear DACs surpassed the metal-based activity benchmark. With advantageous limiting potentials of −0.75, −0.39, −0.74, −0.85, and −0.47 V, respectively, Ti2-, V2-, TiV-, VCr-, and VTa-Pc all had the potential to inhibit HER significantly, and their performance outperformed that of the majority of NRR electrocatalysts have been reported. 3.3 Nanocluster catalysts Nanocluster catalysts are ultra-small sized catalysts composed of tens to hundreds of atoms. The highly distributed and regulated catalytic activity of nanoclusters can be obtained via sensible design and synthesis. The benefits of nanocluster catalysts are stability, selectivity, and high catalytic activity and the catalytic performance of the catalyst could be maximized by controlling the size effect and interface effect, which also affects the pace and product distribution of the catalytic process [150]. Table 3 indicates the summary of the heterogeneous electrocatalysts for NRR under ambient conditions. 3.3.1 Metal nanocluster catalysts Noble metal nanoclusters such as Au, Ag, Pd and Ru have excellent electron transfer ability and catalytic activity, showing good performance in NRR. Due to its distinct electronic structure and catalytic activity, nano-gold is considered to be a versatile electrocatalyst for noble metal nitrogen reduction. Bao et al. [17] first reported the excellent catalytic performance of icosahedral Au nanorods (THH Au NRs) for NRR at room temperature and pressure. When the potential was 0.05 V vs. RHE, the FE was 0.14 %. When the applied voltage was −0.2 V, the maximum ammonia synthesis rate was 1.648 µg h-1 cm-2, with a total FE of 4.0 %. Compared with other materials, hollow nanostructures not only have a larger specific surface area, but also exhibit higher activity in NRR due to the synergistic effect of their inner and outer surfaces [176]. El-Sayed et al. [151] applied hollow nanocage gold (Au HNCs) to an electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction and loaded it on an indium tin oxide (ITO) substrate. In 0.5 M LiClO4 electrolyte at 20 °C, Au HNCs outperformed other gold nanocatalysts (such as gold nanocubs, gold nanospheres, and gold nanorods) in terms of nitrogen reduction catalytic performance. Three times the Au nanocube's (11.4 %) maximum FE, or 30.2 %, was achieved at −0.5 V vs. RHE together with a maximum ammonia synthesis rate of 3.9 μg h-1 cm-2. Furthermore, the FE of Au HNCs increased to 40.5 % at 50 °C. Very recently, the mechanism of Au3Cu alloy nanoparticles in ENRR was revealed. It is found that the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect of these nanoparticles can promote the transfer of the hot electrons of plasma from Au atoms to Cu atoms, realize the redistribution of electrons between atoms and boost the formation of ammonia. The yield increased by 93.9 % [177]. Ag as electrocatalysis nitrogen reduction has the potential to one of the elements in catalyst, abundant reserves, by its nature has good cost effectiveness. Both Ag-based single atom catalysts and nanocatalysts have excellent catalytic ability. Huang et al. [154] demonstrated that Ag nanosheets exhibited an ammonia synthesis rate of 4.62 × 10–11 mol s-1 cm-2 and a FE of 4.8 % (−0.6 V vs. RHE). This research finding, along with other reports, collectively demonstrates that halide anions anchored on the catalyst surface can inhibit hydrogen evolution. On top of that, Yin and colleagues [178] disclosed the use of Ag triangular nanosheets with sharp edges (AgTPs) as catalysts, and potassium ions were used as accelerators (cocatalysts) in nitrogen reduction of ammonia synthesis. Under the action of potassium ion additive, the FE of AgTPs is 25 % at a potential of −0.25 V vs. RHE, and the ammonia synthesis rate was 58.5 mg gAg -1 h-1, which is better than the performance of Ag nanoparticles (FE is 16 %, the ammonia synthesis rate is 38 mg gAg -1 h-1). Nanoporous Pd is also one of the potential catalysts for NRR. Deng et al. [157] employed oxygen-rich tannic acid-modified Pd nanoparticles as electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction catalysts. When the voltage was −0.45 V vs. RHE, the maximum NH3 yield was 24.12 μg h-1 mgcat. −1 and the FE was 9.49 %, which is superior to pure Pd nanoparticles and other reported palladium-based catalysts. Furthermore, doping PD-based materials with non-metallic elements (such H or P) could significantly enhance their ability to reduce nitrogen by electrocatalysis. The synthesis ammonia yield of nanoporous palladium hydride was 20.4 µg h-1 mgcat. −1, and its FE was 43.6 % at −0.15 V vs. RHE, according to the related report of Xu et al. [158]. Nanoporous Rh is one of the best catalysts in the synthesis of ammonia. Su et al. [160] reported that RhP2/NPC was synthesized by embedding RhP2 in the N, P co-doped carbon (NPC) skeleton as a catalyst, and the nano-sized RhP2 particles were fixed on the interconnected NPC, which enhanced the accessibility, electronic conductivity and stability of the active site, achieving excellent ammonia synthesis efficiency. They performed 15N isotope experiments to verify NH3's N source. Post-electrolysis electrolyte 1H NMR showed peaks at 7.21–7.33 ppm, matching 15NH4 + standards, confirming N in NH3 comes from supplied N2, not catalyst decomposition. Among transition metals, Mo is one of the promising catalysts for nitrogen reduction. It has been reported that it can be used as nanoclusters to catalyze nitrogen reduction to ammonia synthesis. As is reported by Yang et al., Mo nanomembranes exposed to (110) crystal faces had a higher ammonia synthesis rate than Mo foils [179]. The design of promising cluster modified MXene catalysts is also an important research direction of NRR. An effective remedy is suggested for high-activity NRR catalysts based on MXene and modified with tetranuclear non-noble 3d transition metal clusters (M4). Compared with recognized catalysts of NRR like Ru (0001) (0.43 V) and Au (310) (1.91 V), thermodynamically and kinetically stable Cr4/Ti2CO2 has the lowest overpotential (0.35 V) and high selectivity. In addition, doping Fe in the Cr4 cluster could substantially decrease the kinetic barrier and overpotential by 46 % and 31 %, respectively [180]. As rising star materials, TiO2-based catalyst have been widely reported in the electrocatalysis area [181]. Based on theoretical predictions, Wang et al. [182] conducted a reasonable screening of 16 TiO2-based catalysts and found that Co3, Co1Ni2 and Ni1Mn2@TiO2 catalysts had inhibitory effects on the HER reaction, among which the potential barrier of Co1Ni2@TiO2 was only 0.39 eV. The yield of the experimentally synthesized Co1Ni2@TiO2 ammonia reached 20.396 µg h-1mgcat. −1, and the FE was 13.327 %. 3.3.2 Other nanocluster catalysts As a metal-free electrocatalyst, B4C nanosheets exhibit excellent nitrogen reduction properties and high selectivity under ambient pressure at room temperature. The experimental results of Qiu et al. [161] showed that B4C/CPE can achieve high NH3 yield of 26.57 μg h-1 mgcat. −1 in 0.1 M HCl and 15.95 % high FE (at −0.75 V vs. RHE), endowing high electrochemical stability. Impressively, B4C/CPE showed good NRR activity even in a neutral medium. The DFT calculation further revealed that the * N H 2 − * N H 2 → * N H 2 − * N H 3 reaction was a rate-limiting step. Furthermore, boron nanosheets (BNs) were employed by Zhang et al. as an electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction catalyst [162]. At a voltage of −0.8 V vs. RHE, the ammonia synthesis rate in 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte was 13.22 μg h-1 mgcat. −1, and the FE was 4.04 %. Cyclic test and long-term electrolysis test results indicated that BNs has excellent electrochemical stability. Based on the "like dissolves like" principle, Zhang et al. [163] proposed that highly delaminated few-layer black phosphorus nanosheets (FL-BP NSs) serve as effective nonmetallic catalysts for ENRR. According to simulations using DFT, FL-BP NSs reached a high ammonia synthesis rate of 31.37 μg h-1 mgcat. −1 in ambient circumstances. N2 to NH3 synthesis can be selectively catalyzed through alternative hydrogenation pathways by the active orbitals and electrons of the zigzag and diff-zigzag type edges of FL-BP NSs. Moreover, Wang and co-workers introduced a novel type of bullet-like M-Te (M represents Ru, Rh, Ir) glassy porous nanorods (PNRs) as superior electrocatalysts for NRR. Using potassium tellurite (K2TeO3), an effective hydrothermal method was employed to create the glassy IrTe4 PNRs and sodium hexachloroiridate (III) hydrate (Cl6H2IrNaO3) as metal precursors. HAAD-STEM and TEM showed that the product exhibit a 1D nanostructure (Fig. 14 a) and a porous bullet-like profile (Fig. 14b), while Ir and Te were evenly distributed the PNRs (Fig. 14f). The optimized IrTe4 PNRs were among the most active NRR electrocatalysts reported to date on account of their considerable ammonia yield rate (51.1 μg h-1 mgcat. −1) and FE (15.3 %) at −0.2 V vs. RHE, as well as their long-term stability of up to 20 consecutive cycles (Fig. 14e) [164]. The influence of cluster size on catalytic performance is a critical aspect in the field of ENRR. Reducing the size of nanoclusters significantly enhances catalytic activity. Smaller nanoclusters expose more active sites due to a higher proportion of surface atoms with unsaturated coordination. For instance, Jin et al. [183] reported that amorphous Ru nanoclusters with a size of 1.2 nm supported on carbon nanotubes achieved an NH3 yield of 10.49 μg h-1mg-1at −0.2 V vs. RHE, 4.6 times higher than that of conventional crystalline Ru nanoclusters. Additionally, quantum confinement effects become more pronounced as the cluster size decreases, optimizing the electronic structure and promoting the adsorption and activation of reactants. Theoretical calculations demonstrated that Fe3 and Fe4 clusters supported on nitrogen - doped graphene (N4G) exhibited superior NRR activity with a lower limiting potential (−0.45 V) compared to single - atom and Fe dimer catalysts, owing to enhanced N₂ adsorption enabled by optimized electronic configurations [184] . Moreover, the size of clusters directly affects the reaction pathway and product selectivity. Smaller clusters favor the adsorption and cleavage of the NN bond, promoting NH3 formation via distal or alternating mechanisms. However, extremely small clusters may exacerbate the competitive HER, reducing NH3 selectivity. Small-sized clusters tend to aggregate or dissolve under reaction conditions due to high surface energy, severely compromising catalytic stability. Carrier or ligand engineering emerges as a crucial strategy to address this issue. For example, Yang and colleagues [185] demonstrated that ultrafine (sub-2 nm) Au25(PET)18 clusters supported on sulfur-doped graphene (S-G) enabled stable ENRR performance. At −0.5 V, this catalyst achieved an NH₃ yield of 27.5 μgNH₃·mgAu -1h-1with a Faradaic efficiency of 2.3 %. Notably, it retained 80 % of its NRR activity after continuous operation for four days, compared to only 15 % activity retention for clusters supported on undoped graphene, confirming that optimized support materials can significantly enhance the structural stability of small-sized clusters. 4 Conclusion and perspectives To date, electrochemical nitrogen reduction is a promising green technology for converting nitrogen into useful ammonia. Although some progress has been made, it still faces many challenges, such as the competition of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), low reaction selectivity, and short catalyst lifetime. In reality, the verification of NRR catalyst activity is prone to false positives, especially in aqueous systems. Some previously reported catalysts (e.g., Bi, Mo/MoS2, Sn (II) Pc and Nb/V-N) have been strictly verified and may originate from environmental pollutants, experimental interference or non-catalytic reactions [186–188]. This phenomenon not only reflects the challenges of the NRR reaction itself, such as low yield and susceptibility to contamination, but also exposes the limitations of the validation methods in earlier studies. Therefore, strict verification methods such as 15N2 labeling, control experiments, and impurity removal are required to distinguish the authenticity [189–191]. The efficiency of NH3 production by electrochemical methods is still far from industrial-level production. In order to improve the NRR performance of electrocatalysis, several aspects worth exploring in future research are as follows. 4.1 Air source airRR Air source selection is one of the critical elements influencing the effectiveness of the NRR. At present, the preponderance of research endeavors within the field of NRR employ pure nitrogen as the reactant gas. However, in real-world applications, the concentration of nitrogen is considerably lower, and it is typically found in a mixture with other atmospheric components, commonly known as air. Consequently, there is an imperative for future scholarly investigations to address the complexities inherent in the NRR process when it operates in the presence of competition from oxygen. This necessitates a more nuanced understanding of the interplay between nitrogen reduction and the potential interference from oxygen, which is crucial for the development of practical and efficient NRR technologies. Concurrently, water and carbon dioxide represent pivotal air sources; hence, their influence on the NRR warrants thorough investigation. 4.2 OER+NRR: bifunctional electrocatalysts In recent years, remarkable progress has been made in the development of bifunctional electrocatalysts [192], especially in the areas of oxygen reduction (ORR), oxygen evolution reactions (OER) and HER. Researchers have focused on developing bi-functional catalysts such as MXene-based [193,194], MOFs and their derivatives [195,196], doped nanosheets [197,198] to improve the overall energy conversion efficiency. Through the inherent correlation of electron transfer, OER and NRR provide an effective synergy in the bifunctional catalytic system. The OER at the anode releases electrons through a sequence of oxidation processes ( 2 H 2 O → O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e − ), whereas the NRR at the cathode produces NH3 with the precise participation of 6 electrons. As a result, a self-circulating system is developed that enables the NRR to directly utilize the electrons generated by the OER. Furthermore, OER and NRR are complementary in acidic and alkaline environments. While NRR consumes H+ in neutral or acidic circumstances and OH- in alkaline ones, OER consumes OH- in alkaline conditions and produces H+ in acidic ones. By migrating between electrodes, the electron-driven proton/OH- maintains local pH stability and keeps the process from being blocked by an excessive deviation. Li et al. [199] synthesized 2D bimetal–MOFs (CoxFe–MOF) nanosheets with a thickness of 10 nm and applied them to OER and NRR in alkaline medium. In 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, the performance of the optimized Co3Fe-MOF (280 mV at 10 mA cm-2, 38 mV at dec‑1) was better than that of commercial RuO2 (351 mV at 10 mA cm-2, 99 mV at dec‑1). At the same time, Co3Fe-MOF had 25.64 % FE at 0.2 V, and the corresponding NH3 yield was 8.79 μg h-1 mgcat. −1. Sun et al.
