[200] have also developed a superior bi-functional OER/NRR catalyst based on template-assisted Co3O4 − x /GO sandwich structure. Therefore, the construction of bifunctional electrocatalysts of OER and NRR can catalyze two reactions in the same electrochemical system, which might simplify the design and operation of electrolytic devices and reduce costs. Utilizing the electric energy of the cathode and anode simultaneously increases the entire energy conversion efficiency of system. However, many factors must undoubtedly be considered while constructing bifunctic catalysts given that OER and NRR possess distinct reaction properties. For instance, there are differences in the optimal overpotential between the two, which can be addressed by designing spatially separated heterostructured catalysts that integrate but separate the OER sites from the NRR sites, ensuring that the two reactions proceed at their respective appropriate potentials while retaining the electron transfer coupling. 4.3 Restrain HER and other aspects NRR and HER are two competitive reactions, so it is necessary to control HER to improve the selectivity of NRR. In aqueous systems, the competitive inhibition of NRR by HER is nearly universal. Even for catalysts theoretically predicted to possess high selectivity, the high reactivity of H+/H2O in practical testing often leads to the HER becoming the main electron consumption pathway. For instance, Du et al. [201] demonstrated that the stable reduction current originated entirely from HER rather than NRR in the chronograph current test at −0.2 V vs. RHE. Therefore, under the premise of acknowledging that HER has almost universal advantages over NRR, it is crucial to actively control HER to enhance the selectivity of NRR. Inhibiting HER can enhance the selectivity of NRR reaction, while increasing the lifetime of catalyst can reduce the production cost. Currently, several studies have explored ways to inhibit HER using materials such as metal sulfides, nitrides, and oxides. To suppress HER in electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction, it is usually achievable through various methods such as designing nanostructures to weaken the binding of adsorbed H to active sites, introducing defects to adjust the surface adsorption performance of reaction intermediates and restricting the transport of low-energy electrons and protons on the catalyst surface. However, when exploring general strategies for suppressing HER, it is worth noting that a completely universal method applicable to all catalysts has not yet been found. Different types of catalysts such as metals, oxides, and single-atom catalysts often require targeted adjustments. Consequently, future work merits attention towards the synergistic optimization of multiple facets to enable more efficient and selective reaction regulation. 4.4 Rare earth-based catalysts Rare earth-based catalysts are typically regarded as unreactive in electrochemical processes at ambient temperature, so only a few studies have used them as catalysts or carriers. However, the abundant electron orbitals of rare earth elements facilitate the formation of robust coordination with anions on the support, which is conducive to the preparation of catalysts, thus giving these atoms different catalytic properties. At present, research on rare earth-based nitrogen reduction electrocatalysts mainly focuses on single metals such as La, Ce, Sm, Sc, and Y, or their corresponding metal oxide systems. For example, Quan et al. [202] found that loading single-atom La (LaSACs/FL-MoS2) onto MoS2 nanosheets could increase the NH3 yield to 3.68 µg h-1cm-2, and improve the FE by approximately 18 %, which were 9.4 times and 4.7 times that of pure MoS2, respectively. Moreover, based on the lanthanide contraction effect, rare earth oxides such as CeO2 can form abundant intrinsic oxygen defects. Li et al. [203] constructed Fe-doped CeO2 multi-shell hollow microspheres Fe-CeO2HM by hydrothermal method. In the 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte, the ammonia yield reached 34.79 µg h-1mgcat. −1 and the FE reached 36.66 %. Wu et al. [204] regulated the atomic ratio of the ZrxCe1-xO2 solid solution and synthesized Zr0.9Ce0.1O2, which exhibited the optimal performance: FE of 62.68 % was achieved at a potential of −1.3 V vs. Ag/AgCl, and the ammonia production rate reached 9.34 × 10–11 mol cm-2 s-1 at −1.35 V vs. Ag/AgCl. Reaction pathway analysis based on in-situ ATR-SEIRAS technology confirmed that the process followed the association mechanism. Cheng et al. [205] revealed that at a potential of −0.6 vs RHE, the maximum NH3 synthesis rate of Sm2O3 NPs is 27.2 µg h-1mgcat. −1, and the maximum FE is 11.5 %. The combination of reduced graphite (RGO) and Sm2O3 NPs (Sm2O3/RGO) can enhance its electron transport capacity and improve the kinetics of the electrocatalytic reaction, with the maximum synthesis rate of NH3 reaching 51.4 µg h-1mgcat. −1. Additionally, DFT calculations demonstrated that the addition of sulfur dopants and oxygen vacancies significantly lowers the adsorption energy barrier of N2 for S-Sm(OH)3 [206]. Unconventional six-coordination structures are often formed in bigger carbon defects when Y and Sc single atoms are placed onto N-doped carbon nanosheets. Liu et al. [56] calculated and analyzed the possible reaction pathways and mechanisms of NRR on rare earth SACs, and prepared Y- and Sc-based single-atom catalysts (Y1/NC, Sc1/NC). The top of Y atom was favorable for end-on adsorption of N2, while Sc atoms tended to adsorb NRR on the side-on of N2. They both had more favorable N2 adsorption energy, respectively −0.141 and −0.885 eV. Element doping to regulate the electronic structure can enhance the stability of the catalysts. Ren et al. [207] proposed a strategy of using Y3+to replace Li+. By regulating the local electronic structure, the generation of oxygen defects was suppressed, and the cycling stability was enhanced. In the research of rare earth-based catalysts, the doping regulation of similar elements also has reference value. Looking forward, the development of rare earth SACs holds promise for advancing nitrogen fixation technologies, offering a new avenue for efficient and sustainable electrochemical conversion processes. 4.5 Economic viability of catalyst design The practical implementation of electrochemical NRR hinges on cost-effective catalyst design, where balancing activity and material expense is paramount. Noble metals (e.g., Ru, Ir, Pd) exhibit promising NRR performance but face scalability barriers due to scarcity and exorbitant costs (>$170,000/kg for Ir). Non-noble alternatives offer compelling solutions: Rare earth-based systems (e.g., CeO2, Sm2O3) reduce raw material costs by >90 % ($5–100/kg for CeO2) while achieving competitive metrics; Transition metal compounds (e.g., MoS2, Fe-doped oxides) further lower costs (< $20/kg) and enable scalable synthesis, though their moderate activity necessitates defect engineering optimizations. Future research should focus on developing cost-effective synthesis methods for non-noble catalysts and exploring hybrid materials that combine the advantages of both noble and non-noble components. This would not only reduce the overall cost of the technology but also enhance its scalability and commercial potential. coredata.dc:description: The electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) has emerged as a potentially excellent substitute to the highly resource-intensive Haber-Bosch process for ammonia synthesis, attracting a surge of interest among researchers and industry professionals in recent years. Nevertheless, the selectivity and Faradaic efficiency (FE) of the NRR in solution are significantly diminished, which necessitates an intensive search for efficient and selective nitrogen electrocatalysts to improve the reaction performance. This review meticulously surveys the advancements in single-atom (SACs), dual-atom (DACs), and nanocluster nitrogen-fixing electrocatalysts that have been made in recent times. It encompasses a detailed exploration of the pathway and mechanism of the NRR, as well as an analysis of the various types of electrocatalysts and their distinctive features. Moreover, the review underscores the challenges inherent in this reaction, discusses catalyst design strategies that have been employed to address these obstacles, and highlights potential avenues for enhancing the overall efficiency and effectiveness of nitrogen fixation processes.
